title: RS22272
content: The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA), amended by the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 (BCRA), regulates "federal election activity," including voter registration drives, voter identification, get-out-the-vote drives, and public communications that refer to federal candidates. Public communications are defined as various forms of media made to the general public. The Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) regulates "federal election activity," including public communications related to federal candidates. Regulated federal funds, or "hard money," are used for these activities. The FEC exempted Internet communications from campaign finance regulation after the BCRA amendments in 2002. In response to the FEC exempting Internet communications from federal campaign finance regulation in 2002, Representatives Shays and Meehan filed suit against the FEC, arguing that this could lead to circumvention of federal campaign finance laws. The U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia agreed with the BCRA sponsors in Shays v. FEC in 2004, overturning the FEC's regulations on political communications on the Internet. The District of Columbia overturned FEC regulations on political communications on the Internet in response to a lawsuit by Representatives Shays and Meehan. The court found that excluding Internet communications from the definition of "public communication" was inconsistent with the BCRA definition. The FEC was tasked with determining what constitutes "general public political advertising" online. The court overturned FEC regulations on political communications on the Internet, finding that excluding Internet communications from the definition of "public communication" was inconsistent with the BCRA definition. The court left it to the FEC to determine what constitutes "general public political advertising" online and criticized the FEC for not providing adequate notice to the public regarding the definition of "generic campaign activity." The court overturned FEC regulations on Internet communications, stating that they cannot be considered "coordinated communications" subject to FECA regulation. The court found the FEC rule exempting Internet communications from the definition of "public communications" contradicted Congress's intent. The case was remanded to the FEC for further action. The court overturned FEC regulations on Internet communications, stating they cannot be considered "coordinated communications" under FECA. The ruling contradicted Congress's intent, leading to the case being remanded to the FEC for further action. In response, the FEC published an NPRM seeking comments on amending the definition of "public communication" to include paid Internet advertisements. The proposed rules aimed to ensure political transparency. The FEC approved new regulations in March 2006 for Internet activities and communications, exempting certain activities from contribution and expenditure definitions. This decision followed a public hearing in June 2005 and was influenced by the 2004 Shays v. FEC court ruling. The regulations aimed to balance political committee financing and disclosure requirements with individual citizens' freedom to speak online about candidates and elections. In March 2006, the FEC unanimously approved new regulations for Internet activities, citing the 2004 Shays v. FEC court ruling. The regulations aimed to exempt blogs maintained by individuals from FECA regulation, as long as no fee is involved. The Commission recognized the importance of preventing corruption while promoting the Internet as a forum for free speech and information exchange. The FEC proposed regulations to treat paid Internet advertising as "public communication" but exclude other Internet communications from this definition. The regulations only apply when money is exchanged for campaign advertisements online, subjecting them to FECA limitations and reporting requirements. The FEC regulations define paid Internet ads as "public communications," subjecting them to FECA limitations and disclosure requirements. Disclaimer statements are required on political committee websites for all public communications. Fees for political ads on the internet are subject to FECA limits, source restrictions, and disclosure requirements. Disclaimers are required on paid internet ads that advocate for or against a federal candidate. Payments to bloggers by candidates must be disclosed on candidate statements, but disclaimers are not required on blog sites. Payments to bloggers by candidates must be disclosed on candidate statements, but disclaimers are not required on blog sites. Internet advertisements placed on another website for a fee and coordinated with a candidate are considered in-kind contributions subject to FECA limits and disclosure requirements. News stories, commentaries, and editorials distributed online are exempt from FECA coverage. During Congress's consideration of BCRA in 2001 and 2002, the exemption of news stories, commentaries, and editorials distributed online from FECA coverage was not addressed. Individual or volunteer activity on the Internet to influence a federal election is excluded from FECA regulation. During the 109th Congress, there were discussions about exempting all Internet communications from regulation under FECA. Representative DeLay's amendment to exempt Internet communications from regulation was defeated in a vote. H.R. 1606, the Online Freedom of Speech Act, failed to pass in the House. The bill was later ordered favorably reported by the House Administration Committee but the vote was postponed pending FEC regulatory action. During the 109th Congress, there were discussions about exempting Internet communications from FECA regulation. Two bills were offered in response to concerns about circumventing FECA: H.R. 4194 (Shays-Meehan) excluded Internet communications from regulation but regulated communications on websites for a fee, and H.R. 4900 (Allen-Bass) exempted most individual online communications below a dollar threshold from regulation. The vote on the Online Freedom of Speech Act was postponed pending FEC regulatory action. During the 110th Congress, there was a delay in House floor action on H.R. 4900 (Allen-Bass) which aimed to exempt most individual online communications below a dollar threshold from FECA regulation. H.R. 894 (Price, NC) proposed extending disclaimer requirements to Internet communications and was referred to the Committee on House Administration. H.R. 5699 (Hensarling) sought to exempt uncompensated Internet services from being treated as contributions or expenditures. H.R. 5699 (Hensarling) aimed to exempt uncompensated Internet services from being treated as contributions or expenditures, including blogs and electronic publications. It was referred to the Committee on House Administration.
